Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Priorities in the Safety and Sustainability of Blood Banks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many life-saving medical treatments rely on an adequate and safe blood supply for transfusion, during childbirth, surgery, emergency care, and therapy for patients with blood-based diseases. A finite resource, blood relies on volunteer donors and successful public outreach campaigns. Blood services must also ensure the safety of the supply, namely monitoring the donation process to prevent the transmission of blood borne infections (including HIV) and mitigating adverse health effects on patients and donors. Focusing on the concerns of sustainability and safety, this project will examine various practical and social aspects of blood supply, ranging from donor marketing and recruitment to the implementation of donor management information systems, as well as the efficient hospital use of blood. Findings from this project, which trains a graduate student in methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, will be disseminated to organizations that manage and develop policy related to blood safety practices. The research also fosters international scientific cooperation, and will broaden participation of an underrepresented group in the sciences.

Emily Avera, under the supervision of Dr. Sherine Hamdy of Brown University, will explore what factors are prioritized in the maintenance of safety in blood banks. The project will take place primarily in South Africa, where the blood services have established one of the most stringent and effective blood safety systems in the world. Blood safety officials' are concerned with diversity and sustainability. They advocate for increased donor participation from a more diverse cross-section of the populace (e.g. youth, various ethnicities), as matter of sustainability not only for social representation, but to also leverage the statistical correlation of different blood types with certain populations. Equipped with anthropology training, the researcher is well positioned to address the pertinent cultural and symbolic meanings attached to blood, alongside the social issues related to health equity and safety. In addition to an incredibly diverse population, South African blood services must also reckon with chief societal challenges such as high HIV prevalence and equitable resource distribution. To analyze how South African institutions have dealt with these challenges, the researcher will conduct regular long-term observation and data collection of activities in blood services' offices, donor outreach drives, blood safety NGO's, and a public hospital hematology unit, as well as interviews with organizational staff, patients, and donors. The researcher will also analyze relevant educational materials and media to assess linguistic and cultural aspects of developing effective, scientifically sound public communication about blood safety and donation. The findings of this project will directly contribute to evaluating and improving donor outreach and education, safety measures, blood service information management, and efficient and equitable distribution of the blood supply not only in South Africa, but in a majority of countries - including the U.S. - where transfusion medicine is used.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Co-PI Emily Avera has completed the research for her dissertation in relation to the NSF doctoral dissertation research grant entitled “Priorities in the Safety and Sustainability of Blood Banks[Services].” Under the auspices of NSF funding, the research activities included fieldwork in 2018-2019 with the South African National Blood Service (SANBS), the Western Cape Blood Service (formerly Western Province Blood Transfusion Service), and a public hospital hematology department in South Africa. This fieldwork and the data collected are now being used to address the key research questions about practices around safe blood and supply sustainabilty and how the language of blood travels through different social contexts. Avera is in the process of writing a doctoral dissertation based on this research and its findings for expected completion in May 2020.

The project contributes to anthropology and science and society studies. Avera and PI Paja Faudree have presented research and a panel discussion on linking linguistic and medical subfields of anthropology at the flagship anthropology conference in the U.S. The contribution of the project also includes adding to the discussion in anthropology around community health outreach and blood donor recruitment as Avera discusses in both her in-progress dissertation and in several research presentations delivered in the U.S., South Africa, and internationally. Avera has also presented on labor and automation drawn from research into lab operations of South African blood services at the flagship conference for science and technology studies in the U.S.

During fieldwork, Avera also co-developed and co-taught an ethnographic interview methods training with an applied anthropologist colleague to enable a South African National Blood Service research team to conduct their own study related to a larger research initiative with the blood systems research institute (U.S.). The study now been completed and they are currently writing up findings and recommendations for blood service policy and practice. During the grant period, Avera also created and taught a qualitative research workshop for SANBS. Personnel from a wide range of their departments attended. The workshop was designed to introduce SANBS staff to qualitative research methods and provide concrete examples of how they may apply these methods to their work at the blood services. Avera also drew up a qualitative research resource guide for workshop participants. This workshop and guide can be used in future to make this training available for more blood service professionals. These trainings have empowered blood service staff to understand the benefits of qualitative research that can apply to their work thereby increasing their research capacity and ability to draw upon qualitative research resources more efficaciously and better envision future partnerships with qualitative researchers.

 

During the grant period, Avera also was in dialogue with Jembi Health Systems and learned about their blood safety information systems project which was developed with their team in South Africa and rolled out in other locations globally. In addition, Avera coordinated with Safe Blood for Africa to begin work on a blood safety document database that will be made available via an open access platform in partnership with the Brown University’s Digital Repository and data management library staff. The materials in this database include blood safety training materials, work instructions, and other important archival media related to Safe Blood for Africa’s work both with partners in South Africa and abroad, primarily in the African region in blood services with limited resources. This database, once fully completed, will serve as an archive of Safe Blood for Africa’s work as a longstanding global health organization, with resources that can be utilized by blood service practitioners both in the U.S., South Africa, and internationally to adapt for their own operations and research interests. Other researchers interested in global health and history of medicine may also use this corpus of materials for further research. Avera presented this work at the African Society for Blood Transfusion congress in 2018 to publicize this project to blood service practitioners. Avera also presented this work as an example for librarians assisting others on developing the broader impacts component of NSF proposals.
